p: Many toxic secondary metabolites are stored in the plants producing them in an inactive form, and juglone is no exception. In 1950, Daglish [ 264] showed that walnut nuts contain juglone as glycoside of 1,4,5-trihydroxynaphtalene and not as α-hydrojuglone, as previously suggested. Later on, various species from the Juglandaceae family showed that juglone accumulates in their tissues in its glycosylated form, hydrojuglone glucoside (HJG; 1,5-dihydroxy-4-naphthalenyl-β-D-gluco- pyranoside) to reduce its autotoxicity [ 265]. The release of juglone from glycoside occurs in plants in two stages: first, β-glucosidase catalyzes hydrolysis to hydrojuglone, which then is chemically oxidized to form a toxic juglone [ 199].
